facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1452 of 1973 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1452 of 1973. Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment Order dated the 8th September 1971 of the Punjab Haryana High Court in P. A. No. 689 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated 8 September 1971 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in P.A. No. 689 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment Order dated the 8th September 1971 of the Punjab Haryana High Court in P. A. No. 689 of 1970. C. Mahajan, M. R. Agnihotri and Urmila Sirur, for the appellants K. Garg, S. C. Agarwal, S. S. Bhatnagar and V. J. Francis, for respondents Nos. 1, 3, 5, 6, 7 17.

facts.text: Principal question is whether appellants are wrongly shown as junior to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: RAY, C.J.-This appeal is by special leave from the judgment dated 8 September, 1971 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana. The principal question raised in this appeal is whether the appellants are wrongly shown as junior to the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents treated senior to appellants based on Punjab Co-operative Subordinate Service Rules, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents have been treated to be senior to the appellants on the basis of the Punjab Co-operative Subordinate Service Rules, 1936 hereinafter referred to as the 1936 Rules. Under the 1936 Rules seniority is dependent on the passing of departmental examination.

facts.text: Appellants passed departmental examination after respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Under the 1936 Rules seniority is dependent on the passing of departmental examination. The appellants passed the departmental examination after the respondents had done so. Therefore, the appellants are treated as junior to the respondents.

facts.text: Appellants belonged to Pepsu Service.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants belonged to Pepsu Service. On 20 October, 1956, the appellants had been removed from the position of Sub-Inspectors to Inspectors On 1 November, 1956 there was the reorganization of the State of Punjab.

facts.text: On 20 October 1956, appellants were promoted from Sub-Inspectors to Inspectors.

anchor.surface_text: On 20 October, 1956, the appellants had been removed from the position of Sub-Inspectors to Inspectors On 1 November, 1956 there was the reorganization of the State of Punjab. Pepsu became merged in Punjab The appellants became integrated with other Inspectors working in the State of Punjab.

facts.text: On 1 November 1956, reorganization of State of Punjab occurred and Pepsu merged into Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 November, 1956 there was the reorganization of the State of Punjab. Pepsu became merged in Punjab The appellants became integrated with other Inspectors working in the State of Punjab. On 1 March, 1957 the appellants were reverted from the position of Inspector to Sub-Inspector.

facts.text: Appellants integrated with other Inspectors in Punjab after merger.

anchor.surface_text: Pepsu became merged in Punjab The appellants became integrated with other Inspectors working in the State of Punjab. On 1 March, 1957 the appellants were reverted from the position of Inspector to Sub-Inspector. On 11 April, 1957 the appellants were promoted again to the position of Inspector.

facts.text: On 1 March 1957, appellants reverted from Inspector to Sub-Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 March, 1957 the appellants were reverted from the position of Inspector to Sub-Inspector. On 11 April, 1957 the appellants were promoted again to the position of Inspector. The appellants contend that the 1936 Rules did not apply to Pepsu before the merger

facts.text: On 11 April 1957, appellants promoted again to Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: On 11 April, 1957 the appellants were promoted again to the position of Inspector. The appellants contend that the 1936 Rules did not apply to Pepsu before the merger, and, therefore, the conditions of service could not be varied to their disadvantage after the integration without the previous approval of the Central Government as provided by section 115(7) of the States Reorganization Act.

facts.text: Appellants contend 1936 Rules did not apply to Pepsu before merger.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the 1936 Rules did not apply to Pepsu before the merger, and, therefore, the conditions of service could not be varied to their disadvantage after the integration without the previous approval of the Central Government as provided by section 115(7) of the States Reorganization Act.

facts.text: Appellants lost one month and eleven days due to reversion between 1 March 1957 and 11 April 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also contend that they have lost one month and eleven days on account of reversion from the position of Inspector to Sub-Inspector between 1 March, 1957 and 11 April, 1957. The gradation list was published on 11 March. 1966.

facts.text: Gradation list published on 11 March 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The gradation list was published on 11 March. 1966. The seniority list was prepared on the basis of 1936 Rules.

facts.text: Seniority list prepared on basis of 1936 Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The seniority list was prepared on the basis of 1936 Rules. Rule 5 of the 1936 Rules states that all candidates for the post of Inspectors and Sub-Inspectors of Co-operative industrial Societies shall undergo such training and shall pass such examination as the Registrar may prescribe.

facts.text: On 1 November 1956, appellants and respondents were all officiating Inspectors.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 November, 1956 the appellants as well as the respondents were all officiating Inspectors. Some of the appellants passed their departmental examination in January, 1959 and some in May, 1961.

facts.text: Some appellants passed departmental exam in January 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the appellants passed their departmental examination in January, 1959 and some in May, 1961. Some of the respondents passed their departmental examination in February, 1957 and the others in March, 1958.

facts.text: Some appellants passed departmental exam in May 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the appellants passed their departmental examination in January, 1959 and some in May, 1961. Some of the respondents passed their departmental examination in February, 1957 and the others in March, 1958.

facts.text: Some respondents passed departmental exam in February 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the respondents passed their departmental examination in February, 1957 and the others in March, 1958. All the respondents who were shown senior to the appellants in the gradation list dated 11 March, 1966 had passed their departmental examination before the appellants passed their examination.

facts.text: Other respondents passed departmental exam in March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the respondents passed their departmental examination in February, 1957 and the others in March, 1958. All the respondents who were shown senior to the appellants in the gradation list dated 11 March, 1966 had passed their departmental examination before the appellants passed their examination.

facts.text: All respondents shown senior passed exam before appellants.

anchor.surface_text: All the respondents who were shown senior to the appellants in the gradation list dated 11 March, 1966 had passed their departmental examination before the appellants passed their examination. The respondents were all confirmed earlier than the appellants.

facts.text: Respondents confirmed earlier than appellants, before 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were all confirmed earlier than the appellants. The confirmation of the respondents took place before 1964. In the High Court it was conceded by the appellants that the respondents had been confirmed earlier than the appellants.

facts.text: In High Court, appellants conceded respondents confirmed earlier.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court it was conceded by the appellants that the respondents had been confirmed earlier than the appellants. The High Court found that the seniority list was prepared on this basis.

facts.text: High Court found seniority list prepared on basis of confirmation for confirmed Inspectors and exam date for others.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the seniority list was prepared on this basis. in the case of confirmed Inspectors the date of confirmation gives the seniority. In the case of Inspectors who were not confirmed the date of passing the departmental examination was taken to be the basis of seniority.

facts.text: Position of Inspectors in integrated seniority list as on 1 November 1956 kept intact.

anchor.surface_text: The position of Inspectors in the integrated seniority list of the former Punjab and Pepsu employees as on 1 November, 1956 was kept intact. In the case of promoted Inspectors selected in the same batch seniority on the basis of the seniority position as Sub- Inspectors was fixed.

facts.text: Central Government issued memorandum No. S.O. SRDI-I-ARM-57 on 11 May 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants that conditions of service have been varied to their disadvantage without the previous approval of the Central Government is utterly unsound. The Central Government on 11 May, 1957 addressed a memorandum No. S.O. SRDI-I-ARM-57 to all State Governments.

facts.text: Memorandum para 2: conditions of service regarding substantive pay etc. protected, but not for departmental promotion.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 2 of the memorandum states that the question of protection to be afforded in the matter of various service conditions to personnel affected by reorganisation was discussed with the State representatives at conferences held with them. After careful consideration of the views expressed at these conferences, the Central Government had decided that the conditions of service in regard to substantive pay of permanent and temporary employees, special pay, leave rules, pension, provident fund and dearness allowance applicable to personnel affected by the reorganisation immediately prior to the appointed day should be protected.

facts.text: Memorandum para 6: State Govts can assume Central Govt approval for specified conditions under proviso to s.115(7) States Reorg Act.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 6 of the memorandum stated that in respect of conditions of service as had been specifically dealt with in the proceeding paragraphs of the memorandum, it would be open to the State Governments to take action in accordance with the decisions conveyed therein and so long as the State Governments acted in conformity with those decisions, they might assume the Central Government approval in terms of the proviso to section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act.

facts.text: Appellants' contention that conditions varied without approval rejected as unsound.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants that conditions of service have been varied to their disadvantage without the previous approval of the Central Government is utterly unsound.

facts.text: Appellants appeared in the examination and availed same method of promotion, no prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also appeared in the examination. They availed of the same method of promotion. They have suffered no prejudice because they passed the departmental examination later than the respondents.

Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment Order dated the 8th September 1971 of the Punjab Haryana High Court in P. A. No. 689 of 1970. C. Mahajan, M. R. Agnihotri and Urmila Sirur, for the appellants K. Garg, S. C. Agarwal, S. S. Bhatnagar and V. J. Francis, for respondents Nos. 1, 3, 5, 6, 7 17.

RAY, C.J.-This appeal is by special leave from the judgment dated 8 September, 1971 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana. The principal question raised in this appeal is whether the appellants are wrongly shown as junior to the respondents.

The respondents have been treated to be senior to the appellants on the basis of the Punjab Co-operative Subordinate Service Rules, 1936 hereinafter referred to as the 1936 Rules. Under the 1936 Rules seniority is dependent on the passing of departmental examination.

issues.text: whether the appellants are wrongly shown as junior to the respondents

anchor.surface_text: RAY, C.J.-This appeal is by special leave from the judgment dated 8 September, 1971 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana. The principal question raised in this appeal is whether the appellants are wrongly shown as junior to the respondents.

issues.text: whether the 1936 Rules did not apply to Pepsu before the merger, and, therefore, the conditions of service could not be varied to their disadvantage after the integration without the previous approval of the Central Government as provided by section 115(7) of the States Reorganization Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the 1936 Rules did not apply to Pepsu before the merger, and, therefore, the conditions of service could not be varied to their disadvantage after the integration without the previous approval of the Central Government as provided by section 11 5 7 of the States Reorganization Act.

issues.text: whether the Central Government memorandum dated 11 May 1957 provides previous approval under section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act for varying conditions of service regarding departmental promotion and examinations

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government on 11 May, 1957 addressed a memorandum No. S.O. SRDI-I-ARM-57 to all State Governments. Paragraph 2 of the memorandum states that the question of protection to be afforded in the matter of various service conditions to personnel affected by reorganisation was discussed with the State representatives at conferences held with them. After careful consideration of the views expressed at these conferences, the Central Government had decided that the conditions of service in regard to substantive pay of permanent and temporary employees, special pay, leave rules, pension, provident fund and dearness allowance applicable to personnel affected by the reorganisation immediately prior to the appointed day should be protected. But so far as conditions of service in regard to travelling allowances, discipline, control, classification, appeal, conduct, probation and departmental promotion were concerned it would not be appropriate to provide any protection in the matter of these conditions. That is stated in paragraph 3 of the memorandum. Paragraph 6 of the memorandum stated that in respect of conditions of service as had been specifically dealt with in the proceeding paragraphs of the memorandum, it would be open to the State Governments to take action in accordance with the decisions conveyed therein and so long as the State Governments acted in conformity with those decisions, they might assume the Central Government approval in terms of the proviso to section 115 7  of the States Reorganisation Act.

arguments.claim: The 1936 Rules did not apply to Pepsu before the merger, and therefore the conditions of service could not be varied to their disadvantage after the integration without the previous approval of the Central Government as provided by section 115(7) of the States Reorganization Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the 1936 Rules did number apply to Pepsu before the merger, and, therefore, the companyditions of service companyld number be varied to their disadvantage after the integration without the previous approval of the Central Government as provided by section 11 5 7 of the States Reorganization Act.

Paragraph 2 of the memorandum states that the question of protection to be afforded in the matter of various service companyditions to personnel affected by reorganisation

arguments.claim: Memorandum dated 11 May 1957 amounts to previous approval under s.115(7) for rules on departmental promotion and examination

anchor.surface_text: In N.A. Raghavendra Rao v. Deputy Commissioner South Kanara, Mangalore  1  a question arose as to whether the Mysore General Services  Revenue Subordinate Branch  Recruitment Rules, 1959 were made with the previous approval of the Central Government under the proviso to section 115, sub- section  7  of the States Reorganisation Act.

arguments.claim: Appellants appeared in the examination, availed same method of promotion, suffered no prejudice by passing later than respondents

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also appeared in the examination. They availed of the same method of promotion. They have suffered numberprejudice because they passed the departmental examination later than the respondents.

holdings.text: The contention of the appellants that conditions of service have been varied to their disadvantage without the previous approval of the Central Government is utterly unsound.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants that conditions of service have been varied to their disadvantage without the previous approval of the Central Government is utterly unsound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Central Government memorandum dated 11 May 1957 in paras 2, 3 and 6 permitted State Governments to vary service conditions regarding departmental promotion and assume prior approval under proviso to s.115(7) of States Reorganisation Act.

holdings.text: It therefore follows from paragraphs 2, 3 and 6 of the aforesaid memorandum that as far as departmental promotion is concerned the Central Government told the State Governments that they might, if they so desired, change the conditions of service and for this purpose they might assume the previous approval of the Central Government as required by the proviso to section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore follows from paragraphs 2, 3 and 6 of the aforesaid memorandum that as far as departmental promotion is concerned the Central Government told the State Governments that they might, if they so desired, change the conditions of service and for this purpose they might assume the previous approval of the Central Government as required by the proviso to section 115 7  of the States Reorganisation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reading of memorandum paras 2 (protects pay etc.), 3 (no protection for promotion etc.), 6 (assume approval if conforming).

holdings.text: It was held there that the memorandum of the Central Government dated 11 May, 1957 amounted to previous approval within the meaning of section 115(7) of the States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was held there that the memorandum of the Central Government dated 11 May, 1957 amounted to previous approval within the meaning of section 115 7  of the States Reorganisation Act. The Mysore General Services  Revenue Subordinate Branch  Recruitment Rules, 1959 were therefore held to be validly made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopting ratio from precedent in N.A. Raghavendra Rao v. Deputy Commissioner and applied in Mohammad Shujat Ali v. Union of India.

holdings.text: The condition of service in regard to passing of departmental examination for the purpose of promotion is therefore, fully clothed with the previous approval of the Central Government.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of memorandum and precedents to the specific condition of passing departmental exam under 1936 Rules for promotion and seniority.

holdings.text: The High Court found that the seniority list was prepared on this basis. in the case of confirmed Inspectors the date of confirmation gives the seniority. In the case of Inspectors who were not confirmed the date of passing the departmental examination was taken to be the basis of seniority.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the seniority list was prepared on this basis. in the case of confirmed Inspectors the date of confirmation gives the seniority. In the case of Inspectors who were not confirmed the date of passing the departmental examination was taken to be the basis of seniority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholding High Court application of 1936 Rules 6 and 7 to facts where respondents confirmed/passed exam earlier than appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore follows from paragraphs 2, 3 and 6 of the aforesaid memorandum that as far as departmental promotion is concerned the Central Government told the State Governments that they might, if they so desired, change the conditions of service and for this purpose they might assume the previous approval of the Central Government as required by the proviso to section 115 7  of the States Reorganisation Act.
